page.title: 12ECOLOGY 3
page.content:
contd from p 11 from Jemimaville and towards the west at Balblair Point. Eelgrass and glasswort cover the sand and cord grass, which was planted to help reclaim land, is abundant on the mud and also the saltings below Gordons Mills. Mussel beds are extensive where the Newhall Burn runs into the saltings. All this provides ideal conditions for the amount of birds to be seen here. Large flocks of wildfowl and waders winter here and the saltmarsh is one of the best places along the Cromarty Firth for seeing large numbers of these birds without leaving the car. Birds that can be seen regularly are mallard, geese, swans, oyster catchers, lapwings, curlews and redshanks.
contd on page 13
